case_title: MUHAMMAD AKBAR JAFFAR vs GOVERNMENT OF BALUCHISTAN

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Akbar Jaffar
allegation: Accumulating wealth through illegal gratifications for issuing permits of second-hand clothing, onions, and potatoes.
Living beyond means and purchasing a house worth Rs. 5 lacs in the name of his mother-in-law, disproportionate to his known sources of income.
Associating and aiding smugglers in smuggling operations.

complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of corruption, living beyond his means, and aiding smugglers in smuggling operations.
investigation_summary: An inquiry was conducted by Mr. Patch Khan Khajjak, Member, Board of Revenue, Baluchistan. The inquiry report found the appellant guilty of living beyond his means and issuing permits indiscriminately, aiding smugglers.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal found procedural defects in the inquiry, including lack of direct evidence, improper framing of charges, and reliance on presumptions. The majority decision allowed the appeal, reinstating the appellant and setting aside the removal order.
punishment: Removal from service (initial order, later overturned)
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed; appellant reinstated with the option for fresh inquiry.
legal_arguments: Violation of mandatory provisions of Rules 5 and 6 of the Baluchistan Civil Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1974
Inquiry Officer exceeded jurisdiction by framing irrelevant questions
No direct evidence presented; reliance on circumstantial evidence and presumptions
Bias alleged against the Inquiry Officer
Failure to appoint a prosecutor and provide a statement of allegations

assets.details: Compensation received for burnt car; no explanation for initial purchase

statutes: Baluchistan Civil Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1974

witness_statement.Chief Goods Clerk: Statements furnished by the Railway Department may be false.

key_issues.finding: Rules 5 and 6 were infringed during the inquiry process.
Charges were based on presumptions and conjectures, not on direct evidence.
Inquiry Officer was found to have acted with bias and overstepped his jurisdiction.
House belonged to the appellant's mother-in-law, and no evidence proved appellant's ownership.

maxims.Presumption of innocence: Charges must be proved beyond reasonable doubt.

words_and_phrases.Living beyond means: Standard of living disproportionate to known income

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around allegations of corruption, procedural defects in inquiry, and reliance on circumstantial evidence. The Tribunal allowed the appeal due to lack of direct evidence and procedural irregularities, reinstating the appellant.

charges.description: Accumulated huge amount of money by accepting illegal gratifications for issuing permits of second-hand clothing, onions, and potatoes.
Assumed a style of living beyond his means and purchased a house worth Rs. 5 lacs in the name of his mother-in-law, disproportionate to his known sources of income.
Associated and mixed up with notorious smugglers and helped them in their smuggling operations.

tribunal_decision.majority_opinion: Appeal allowed due to procedural defects and lack of evidence.
tribunal_decision.minority_opinion: Appeal dismissed, appellant found guilty of charges.

order.instructions: Appellant reinstated in service from 30th March, 1977. Authority may conduct a fresh inquiry through an impartial Inquiry Officer if deemed necessary.
